The ideal engineer is a composite he is not a Scientist,

he is not a Mathematician, he is not a Sociologist or a Writer,

but he may use the knowledge and techniques of any or all of

these disciplines in solving engineering problems

Words of Nathan W. Dougherty

American Civil Engineer

P:04

To establish a unique identity of a pioneer technical Institute

by developing a high-quality technical manpower and

technological resources that aim at economic and social

development of the nation as a whole and the region, in

particular, keeping in view the global challenges.

1. To create a strong and transformative technical educational environment in which fresh

ideas, moral principles, research and excellence nurture with international standards.

2. To prepare technically educated and broadly talented engineers, future innovators and

entrepreneurs, graduates with an understanding of the needs and problems of the industry,

the society, the state and the nation.

3. To inculcate the highest degree of confidence, professionalism, academic excellence and

engineering ethics in budding engineers.

P:07

Message

Sh. Manoj Sinha

Lieutenant Governor, Jammu & Kashmir

Raj Bhavan, Srinagar-190001

I am happy to learn that the National Institute of Technology,

Srinagar, is coming up with the 2020-21 issue of Instituteâs Magazine

âSABZARâ.

I believe such publications are an apt reflection of the institutesâ

values and quality of education, besides providing a platform to

the students to showcase their artistic and creative potential. In

addition to passing exams and securing degrees, students must

also learn to think for themselves and be able to express themselves

with clarity and exactitude.

The process of manifesting ideas and giving them shape onto these

magazines helps in building self confidence of the students, giving

them a sense of accomplishment as they cooperate and indulge

in healthy competition to get their articles published. All these

efforts to showcase creative potential in turn build their capacities

to convey their thoughts cogently and grow into responsible and

accomplished persons in their lives.

I trust that a good number of students and other members of

academic fraternity shall compete to have their professional and

literary contributions accepted for publication in the forthcoming

issue of this e-magazine and I hope âSABZARâ with its quality

content will emerge as a popular magazine among the students

and other readers.

I convey my best wishes to the Director, National Institute of

Technology, Srinagar and to the editorial team and wish them

success in their endeavours.

(Manoj Sinha)

Educationâs purpose is to

replace an empty mind with

an open one.

(Malcolm Forbes)

P:08

Message

I delightfully welcome you to the 2020-21 issue of our annual

magazine Sabzar. Its pages exude the literary and intellectual

flair of NIT Srinagarâs community. The fresh ideas shared by

our dear members mirror the variegated coping mechanisms

adopted in all spheres of life in these challenging times. The

publication of this yearâs issue of the magazine is a symbol of

optimism the Institute has maintained while overcoming the

challenges. This new issue reflects the active engagement

of our students, faculty, and other members of NIT Srinagar

in academic and non-academic activities while adopting a

blend of online and offline modes of participation. I truly

appreciate the hard work put in by the editorial team under

the guidance of Prof. (Dr.) G. A. Harmain (Editor-in-Chief) in

collecting these fresh ideas and giving them a novel shape

for the readers to enjoy.

With this issue too, we continue to give a sense of

belonging to our Institute fraternity and congratulate all for

its publication.

Best Wishes,

Prof. (Dr.) Rakesh Sehgal

If You are planning for a

year, sow rice; if you are

planning for a decade, plant

trees; if you are planning for

a lifetime, educate people

(Chinese Proverb)

Prof. (Dr.) Rakesh Sehgal

Honâble Chairman BoG & Director, NIT Srinagar

P:09

Message

Prof. Kaiser Bukhari

Honâble Registrar, NIT Srinagar

It gives me immense pleasure to present the latest edition of the Sabzar Magazine

brought out by the students, faculty & staff of NIT Srinagar. I congratulate the

students & Staff of NIT Srinagar who have taken the initiative and have contributed

to this edition of the Institute magazine.

Sabzar Magazine has had a rich heritage of showcasing the Talent spectrum available

across the Institute among staff and students at NIT Srinagar. I am sure this new

edition will carry the tradition forward.

Our Institute has a very diverse set of students and faculty who come from all parts

the country. Their versatile inheritance and diverse backgrounds are the strength

of this Institute. I am sure the Institute Magazine shall, therefore, strive to expand

our knowledge about these rich and diverse cultures and also provide a platform to

showcase varied talent at NIT Srinagar.

Lastly, I thank the Director & Patron of Sabzar Magazine, Prof. (Dr.) Rakesh Sehgal for

his encouragement & guidance in bringing out this publication.

I must also congratulate the Editor-in-Chief, Prof. G.A Harmain & his entire editorial

team for successfully bringing out another edition of the magazine in record time.

Best Wishes,

Prof. Kaiser Bukhari

Education is simply the soul

of a society as it passes

from one generation to

another

(G.K. Chesterton)

P:10

Message

I am very grateful to Prof (Dr.) Rakesh Sehgal, Director NIT Srinagar for providing me an opportunity

to serve our fraternity in the capacity of Editor-in-chief of our esteemed annual issue of SABZAR

20-21. Our Institute magazine Sabzar has been around for more than half a century. Sabzar in

several languages connotes green. This name was coined for our magazine when people were yet

to realize the importance of going green and benefits of green technologies for sustained living

on earth. âGo for Green Technologiesâ are the words echoing in almost every corner of the world

in present day scenario due to such issues as climate change, global warming and sustainability.

Sabzar is a reminder to all of us of our responsibilities as engineers, innovators and scientists

to look towards greener ideas, greener technologies and greener innovations. I am immensely

delighted that our latest issue of Institute annual magazine Sabzar 2020-2021 in e-form is at our

finger touch. The aim of our magazine is not to look for masterpieces of art of writing or storey

telling rather to carve spaces for those who may occasionally try their tryst with expression of ideas.

Institute magazines are meant for hunt of such treasure troves of hidden talent which our students

innately possess, that needs to be groomed, cultivated, and tapped. Sabzar provides one of the

platforms for such a milieu and an appropriate environment for nurturing our budding engineers

on a free and fair ground to express their way of looking at things. An honest, innocent and straight

forward perception of sweet and sour faces of life from our young generation is always providing

a flavor of serendipity with the articles which are appearing in this issue of our magazine. You will

definitely find in these pages some glimpses of talent that our Institute is bestowed with, in the

form of several contributions. After reading the magazine, you will be with some questions, with

some answers and with some random thoughts. I am sure that we have been successful in inviting

a large spectrum of articles with diverse themes which like a rainbow has become conspicuous by

its wonderful details. The colors and contours of contributions in this issue are immensely vibrant

and self-explanatory. The extraordinary efforts of students for writing the articles for Sabzar is

appreciated given that exams were hanging around like a sword of Damocles. Their hard work

and cooperation coupled with lot of efforts of editorial team has really been praiseworthy and

overwhelming resulting in the present issue of Sabzar.

The real challenging tasks of this issue of Sabzar 2021, from its inception to the final print were

executed by Dr. Jaya, Dr. Ravi, Mr. M. Zehab and Mr. Syed Hadi. This required perseverance, patience

and taste for artistic aspects of this literary work. All of them displayed enormous willingness to

cooperate at all stages of this mammoth task. Words alone are not enough to express my gratitude

to all the pains they took smilingly while donating a lot of time for this activity.

Best wishes

Prof (Dr.) G. A Harmain

The sun does arise,

And make happy the skies;

The merry bells ring

To welcome the spring;

The skylark and thrush,

The birds of the bush,

Sing louder around

To the bellâs cheerful sound,

While our sports shall be seen

On the Echoing Green.

(William Blake)

Prof. (Dr.) G. A. Harmain

Editor-In Chief

P:12

Message

The gloomy pandemic period seems to have engulfed us all in

a state of despair. But as aptly written by Emily Dickinson in the

quoted lines, hope is ever-present in the human soul. NIT Srinagar

family cradled hope in these tough times and continued to be

creative with words and imagination. This hope broke the walls of

despair, took the shape of words, and came out on the pages of

our annual magazine Sabzar. Therefore, I share my delight with the

institute fraternity at the publication of its 2020-21 issue.

On this occasion, I thank the Honâble Director of the Institute

and Sabzarâs patron Prof. (Dr.) Rakesh Sehgal for rekindling hope

in us and initiating this massive task. I am grateful to Prof. (Dr.)

G. A. Harmain, the Editor-in-Chief, under whose expert guidance

the magazineâs publication was made possible. I also express my

gratitude to Dr. Ravi Bhushan, Associate Editor for his hard work

and coordination. I greatly appreciate the hard work, dedication,

and promptness shown by Mr. Prabh Karan Singh and Ms. Ayushi

Chaudhary, members of the student editorial team for assisting me

in the compilation of the articles.

I congratulate the authors, the editorial team, and the Institute on

this proud moment and thank them for making me a part of it.

Best Wishes,

Dr. Jaya Shrivastava

âHopeâ is the thing with

feathers â That perches in

the soul â And sings the tune

without the words â And

never stops â At all â

(Emily Dickinson)

Dr. Jaya Shrivastava

Associate Editor

The current outbreak of a deadly virus has affected

every stratum of human life, including swotting up

for acquiring knowledge and skills. Every sector is

minimizing its repercussions by switching towards

an online framework. The current education system

of India, which is highly dependent on an offline

framework, is also struggling in developing ways

to switch towards cloud-based learning. As most

of my academic peers from other continents had

already switched to online learning platforms, seeing

their progress in that field made me think that learning

online is far better than learning offline. Being a frosh at NIT

Srinagar makes me competent to form my opinion regarding

the experience with offline as well as online learning and I must

say it has been quite appalling for me to study in the online

environment. Although offline learning has its demerits, the

structure and ethos on which the online learning platform is

based have their shortcomings. In this essay, I will argue why

offline learning is better than online learning in Kashmir.

Online learning platforms are based upon integrated sets of interactive online services, also known

as learning management systems (LMS). Companies providing these services are improving the

LMS now and then thus making it more user-friendly and effective at the same time. This seems to

be an appropriate solution in these circumstances for almost everyone, including the educational

institutes for providing education and study material for its enrolled students. But the users face

difficulty when the internet speed is reduced owing to 2G Network services. As per a survey, the

minimum bandwidth requirement for online learning is 1.5Mbps (both upload and download speed)

and providing even 0.4Mbps on 2G network spectrum: which is implausible, is considered to be an

achievement for telecommunication companies. As a consequence of this, professors and students

spend twice more time than others using the same for uploading/downloading a 10 MB file. Thus,

this limitation makes it quite impractical for a student to study online as âtime is moneyâ.

The predominant impediment of offline learning is infrastructural burdens. To run an Educational

Institute, some prerequisites need to be sufficed, such as having a building. In addition to this,

P:49

a well-established framework is also

required. When all this is achieved,

then only the institution is capable of

delivering knowledge and skills to its

students. Most colleges in India are

already established in accordance with

an offline framework. As a result, the

academic staff is adroitly familiarized

with this environment and curriculum.

Upgrading to an online framework

will require re-establishing some of

the pillars of the existing framework

and training its academic staff before

adapting to the new framework to

work efficiently. All these processes

are tedious thus affecting studentâs

academic performance

The pre-eminent advantage of offline

learning over online is character

development, also reckoned as âThe

College Lifeâ. The curriculum of most of

the online courses is static and moored

whilst in offline mode, not only does

a student attend classes for course

study but also participates in various

activities (such as student governance,

athletics, academic and professional

activities, volunteer and service-related

activities, multicultural activities and

other such activities) which, most of

the time have nothing to do with the

course itself. Social interaction and

adopting a group study environment

are some of the most quintessential

soft skills students develop in their

tenure at college or university as they

are essential to interact productively

and acquire leadership qualities and

teamwork ethics. Attending an offline

course has the advantage that there

is a fixed area of study, thus getting a

sense of productivity and also getting

a lot of things done due to peer

pressure. Lastly, the professorâs realtime interaction with students provides

a chance for them to exchange

doubts, ideas, and views effectively,

thus enabling real-time performance

checking.

In conclusion, it is evident that both

online, as well as offline learning

platforms, have their merits as well

as demerits. Regardless, online

learning is more practical nowadays

as institutes are switching towards it

in the current scenario. In my point of

view, some beneficial factors of online

learning should be incorporated with

the existing offline framework as it is

in human nature to disrelish novelty,

so itâs for the best to have the best of

both worlds. I will leave with a thought

that âwe should always keep a balance

between novelty and familiarityâ.

LESSONS LEARNT

THUS FARâ¦

hen the tide is against you, there is a prevalent belief that you must flow with it.

The issue here is that you have no control over the direction of your life, which

leads to a state of hopelessness. I was a firm believer in this myth and thought it

was the best course of action. It hit me really hard when I started contemplating

the very meaning of my life. It was then that I realized that if you get caught in a tide it only

brings you to a shark-infested ocean, it becomes irrelevant to go with the flow, and not fighting

to change your fate is pointless. Since then, Iâve made a conscious effort to take control of my life

rather than allowing external events to define the terms. Iâve attempted to share the lessons Iâve

learned thus far in the âjugglerâ known as life in the content that follows.

King Midas wishes for the transformation of everything he touches into gold.

When he touches his daughter, she transforms into gold. When he touches his

food, it turns to gold. This is a lesson taught in many myths that tells us that if

we want to develop a highly successful optimization process to maximize any

Artificial intelligence is the science of making machines intelligent. It is the technology

of the future that is going to revolutionize how we live. We have seen it in movies,

we have fantasized about it, and we have read books about it. In fact, for the last

100 years or so, these two words put together make everybody feel amazing.

Some feel it will really enhance their lives, some feel it is the final frontier while

some call it the Holy Grail. The growth of artificial intelligence over the years has

profound implications, particularly when it comes to questions of power and this

is what you will come across through this essay.

Once there is superintelligence, humanityâs fate may be determined by how the

superintelligence acts. Machines will then be better than humans at innovating, and they

will do so on digital timelines. This essentially amounts to a telescoping of the future.

Consider all of the insane technologies that you might have believed humans could have

created in the fullness of time: a cure for aging, colonization of space, self-replicating

nanobots, or uploading of human minds into computers, and other science fiction-y things

that are inconsistent with the laws of physics. There is a great possibility that all such things

could be developed by a superintelligence, and it could happen quickly. A superintelligence

possessing such technological maturity would be tremendously strong, and it would not be

difficult for it to achieve any of its goals. We humans would therefore live in a future fashioned

by the desires of this A.I. Imagine we assign an AI the task of making humans smile. When the

AI is weak, it does useful or humorous things that make the user grin. When the AI becomes

super clever, it learns that there is a more effective way to achieve this goal: take over the

globe and implant electrodes into human face muscles to produce perpetual, beaming grins.

One could argue that if a computer started poking electrodes into peopleâs faces, we would

just turn it off. This is not always easy to do if we have grown dependent on the system, for

example, where is the internetâs off switch?
